title: Copenhagen City
body:
- areas of the city##theardencopencity
	- **Østerbro**
		- charming district 
		- leafy streets
		- elegant townhouses
		- relaxed atmosphere
		- picturesque parks, such as Fælledparken
		- green spaces for recreation and leisure
		- diverse culinary scene
		- trendy cafes, cozy eateries, and gourmet restaurants
		- wealthy district
	- **Nørrebro**
		- vibrant and diverse neighborhood 
		- multicultural atmosphere
		- lively street life
		- eclectic mix of residents
		- students, artists, families, professionals
		- trendy bars, hip cafes, and eclectic shops
		- hub of creativity and innovation
	- **city centre**
		- historic heart of capital
		- charming cobblestone streets
		- colorful facades
		- iconic landmarks 
			- Round Tower
			- Christiansborg Palace
		- architectural marvels spanning centuries
		- medieval churches
		- Renaissance palaces
		- bustling with activity
		- shopping paradise
	- **Christianshavn**
		- picturesque neighborhood 
		- charming canals
		- historic buildings
		- vibrant cultural scene
		- originally founded as a fortified city by Christian IV in the early 17th century
		- trendy and eclectic area
		- artists, intellectuals, young professionals
		- cozy cafes, trendy restaurants, and scenic waterfront views
	- **Island Brygge**
		- waterfront district 
		- stunning views of the harbor 
		- recreational spaces along the waterfront
		- former industrial area 
		- modern and lively neighborhood 
		- trendy cafes, restaurants, and cultural venues
		- waterfront promenade, green parks, outdoor swimming facilities
		- relaxation and leisure
	- **Vesterbro**
		- vibrant street life, trendy bars, eclectic mix of cultures
		- gritty industrial area
		- arts and entertainment scene
		- historic landmarks and bustling squares
	- **Fredericksberg**
		- leafy streets, green parks, elegant architecture
		- Frederiksberg Gardens
		- cozy cafes, gourmet restaurants, cultural attractions
		- blends residential charm with urban sophistication

title: Kierkegaard
body:
- links
	- [wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%C3%B8ren_Kierkegaard)
- basic infos
	- 1813-1855
	- the first existentialist philosopher
	- fondness for metaphor, irony, and parables
	- how one lives as a single individual
	- giving priority to concrete human reality over abstract thinking 
	- importance of personal choice and commitment
	- much of his work deals with Christian love
	- explored the emotions and feelings of individuals when faced with life choices
	- where Sartre focused on atheistic existentialism paradigm
		- Kierkegaard focused on Christian existentialism
	- by the turn of the 20th century his writings were translated into French, German, and other major European languages
- life
	- born to an affluent family in Copenhagen
	- mother was maid
	- father well-to-do wool merchant from Jutland
	- figure of Socrates, whom Kierkegaard encountered in Plato's dialogues, would prove to be a phenomenal influence on the philosopher's later interest in irony
	- came to hope that no one would retain their sins once they had been forgiven
	- 1821 to 1830, Kierkegaard attended the School of Civic Virtue
	- went on to study theology at the University of Copenhagen
	- what I really need to do is to get clear about 'what am I to do', not what I must know
		- wanted to 'lead a completely human life and not merely one of knowledge'
- journals
	- Kierkegaard wrote over 7,000 pages in his journals on events, musings, thoughts about his works and everyday remarks
- Regine Olsen and graduation (1837–1841)
	- broken engagement to Regine Olsen (1822–1904)
	- met 1837 and were instantly attracted to each other
	- 1840, Kierkegaard formally proposed to Olsen
	- 1841 broke off engagement
	- had belief that his 'melancholy' made him unsuitable for marriage
	- 1841, Kierkegaard wrote and defended his master's thesis, On the Concept of Irony with Continual Reference to Socrates
- writings
	- Kierkegaard's central writing on religion was Fear and Trembling, and Either/Or is considered to be his magnum opus
- Either/Or
	- 1843 published Either/Or
	- second edition of Either/Or was published early in 1849
	- first published work 
	- it was mostly written during Kierkegaard's stay in Berlin, where he took notes on Schelling's Philosophy of Revelation
	- both A and B are trying to become religious individuals
	- basically an argument about faith and marriage with a short discourse at the end telling them they should stop arguing
	- outlines a theory of human existence, marked by the distinction between an essentially hedonistic, aesthetic mode of life and the ethical life, which is predicated upon commitment
	- the book's central concern is Aristotle's primal question, 'How should we live?'
	- aesthetic 
		- personal, subjective realm of existence, where an individual lives and extracts pleasure from life for its own sake
		- offers the possibility of the highest and lowest experiences
	- ethical
		- the civic realm of existence
		- value and identity are judged and at times superseded by the objective world
		- starts with a conscious effort to choose one's life
		- it is possible to go too far in one direction and lose sight of the self
			- only faith can rescue the individual from these two opposing realms
		- his challenge is for the reader to 'discover a second face hidden behind the one you see, internally, and then in others
	- history
		- Kierkegaard left Copenhagen in October 1841 to spend the winter in Berlin
		- During his stay, Kierkegaard worked on the manuscript for Either/Or, took daily lessons to perfect his German, and attended operas and plays, particularly by Mozart and Goethe. He returned to Copenhagen in March 1842 with a draft of the manuscript, which he completed late that year and published in February 1843
	- Part I
		- nnn
- Christianity
	- Kierkegaard believed God comes to each individual mysteriously

title: Marathon Trip 2024
body:
- before
	- get Danish krone##dandcrook
- pack
	- laptop: keypass, etnotes
- **Fri 2024-05-03**
	- 06:28 leave Berlin
	- 13:34 arrive Copenhagen
	- 15:00 apartment
	- 12:00-19:00 Sparta Hall - pick up race number
- **Sat 2024-05-04**
	- (10:00-19:00 Sparta Hall - pick up race number)
	- 12:00-14:00 Führung durch Christiania & Christianshavn mit lokalem Guide
- **Sun 2024-05-05**
	- 07:30 start area opens
	- 09:30-15:00 *Marathon*
- **Mon 2024-05-06**
	- 14:00-16:30 Tour: Entdecke den Stadtteil Nørrebro
- **Tue 2024-05-07**
	- 07:00-08:00 Jogging mit einem Einheimischen
	- 12:30-14:30 Tour: Besuche über 15 Kopenhagener Sehenswürdigkeiten mit Einheimischen (mit Annemarie)
	- 16:00-18:30 Tour: Die Kierkegaard-Entdeckung
- **Wed 2024-05-08**
	- 13:26 leave Copenhagen
	- 21:04 return Berlin
